description: Traction elevator components, operation, and maintenance

questions.question: What creates the driving force in a traction elevator?
options: Friction between ropes and the drive sheave
questions.explanation: Traction elevators work through friction (traction) between the hoisting ropes and grooves in the drive sheave. The motor turns the sheave to move the car and counterweight.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the counterweight in a traction elevator?
options: To act as an emergency brake
To balance the car weight and reduce motor load
questions.explanation: The counterweight balances the car weight plus approximately 40% of rated load, reducing the motor power needed and improving energy efficiency.

questions.question: What is the typical counterweight mass compared to the car?
options: Car weight plus 40-50% of rated capacity
questions.explanation: Counterweight is typically set at car weight plus 40-50% of rated capacity. This minimizes motor power requirements across the range of loading conditions.

questions.question: What is the drive sheave?
options: A grooved wheel that hoisting ropes wrap around
questions.explanation: The drive sheave is the grooved wheel at the top of the hoistway connected to the motor. Rope friction in the grooves creates traction to move the car.

questions.question: In a 2:1 roping configuration, how does car travel relate to rope movement?
options: Car moves same distance as rope
Car moves half the distance of rope at sheave
Car moves double the rope distance
questions.explanation: In 2:1 roping, the car moves half the distance that the rope moves at the machine sheave. This doubles the lifting force but halves the speed.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the machine brake?
options: To slow the car during normal operation
To hold the car when stopped and stop it in emergencies
questions.explanation: The machine brake holds the car stationary when stopped at floors and stops the car when power is removed. It's spring-applied, electrically released.

questions.question: What type of motor is commonly used in modern traction elevators?
options: AC induction or permanent magnet motor with VFD
questions.explanation: Modern traction elevators typically use AC induction or permanent magnet motors controlled by variable frequency drives (VFDs) for smooth, efficient operation.

questions.question: What guides the elevator car and counterweight in their travel?
questions.explanation: Steel guide rails run the full height of the hoistway. Guide shoes or rollers on the car and counterweight frames ride on these rails for smooth, controlled travel.

questions.question: What is the purpose of compensation in high-rise traction elevators?
options: To compensate for varying rope weight at different positions
questions.explanation: Compensation chains or ropes balance the varying weight of hoisting ropes as the car moves. Without compensation, the unbalanced rope weight affects system balance.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of hoisting ropes required for traction elevators?
questions.explanation: Traction elevators require a minimum of 3 hoisting ropes. Each rope must be capable of supporting 125% of the full load alone.

questions.question: What is traction ratio and why is it important?
options: Ratio ensuring ropes grip sheave without slipping
questions.explanation: Traction ratio compares the tension on the car side vs. counterweight side of the ropes. It must be maintained to prevent rope slip on the drive sheave.

questions.question: What happens if the hoisting ropes develop excessive slack on one side?
options: Slack rope device activates and stops the elevator
questions.explanation: A slack rope device (governor type) monitors rope tension and activates to stop the elevator if excessive slack develops, preventing unsafe operation.

questions.question: What is the purpose of rope equalizers?
options: To ensure equal tension in all hoisting ropes
To connect ropes to the sheave
questions.explanation: Rope equalizers (hitches) at the car or counterweight allow individual rope adjustment to ensure all ropes carry equal load.

questions.question: What is meant by 'machine room-less' (MRL) elevator?
options: An elevator with the machine located in the hoistway
questions.explanation: MRL elevators have compact machines mounted in the hoistway (typically at the top) instead of a separate machine room, saving building space.

questions.question: What is regenerative braking in elevator systems?
options: Converting kinetic energy back to electrical energy
questions.explanation: Regenerative drives convert the car's kinetic energy back into electrical energy when the car is decelerating or when overhauling (light car going down, heavy car going up).

questions.question: What is the purpose of the deflector sheave?
options: To redirect rope path from machine to car/counterweight
questions.explanation: Deflector (secondary) sheaves redirect the hoisting ropes from the drive sheave to the proper angles for the car and counterweight in the hoistway.

questions.question: How often must hoisting ropes be inspected visually?
questions.explanation: Hoisting ropes require monthly visual inspection for wear, broken wires, corrosion, and other damage. More frequent inspection may be needed based on usage.

questions.question: What triggers rope replacement in traction elevators?
options: When broken wire count or diameter reduction exceeds limits
questions.explanation: Ropes must be replaced when broken wires per strand or per rope length exceed specified limits, or when rope diameter reduction indicates wear.

questions.question: How is rope traction calculated for a traction elevator?
options: Using rope tension ratios and coefficient of friction
questions.explanation: Traction is calculated using the Euler formula: T1/T2 = e^(μα), where μ is friction coefficient and α is wrap angle. This determines if ropes will slip.

questions.question: What is the wrap angle on a traction drive sheave?
options: The angle of rope contact around the sheave
questions.explanation: Wrap angle is the total angle of rope contact around the drive sheave. Greater wrap angle increases traction but also increases rope bending stresses.

questions.question: What is the minimum rope safety factor for traction elevator hoisting ropes?
questions.explanation: ASME A17.1 requires a minimum safety factor of 7.6 for hoisting ropes. This is calculated as rope breaking strength divided by maximum rope load.

questions.question: What is the effect of sheave groove undercutting on traction?
options: Increases traction but reduces rope life
questions.explanation: Undercut grooves increase the effective friction coefficient and traction, but also increase rope pressure and wear rate. Groove profile must balance these factors.

questions.question: For a gearless traction machine, what is the typical motor speed relationship to car speed?
options: Direct drive - sheave speed equals motor speed
questions.explanation: Gearless machines have the drive sheave directly coupled to the motor. Sheave RPM equals motor RPM, so motor speed controls car speed directly.

questions.question: What determines the rated speed of a traction elevator?
options: Sheave diameter and motor RPM (for gearless) or gear ratio (for geared)
questions.explanation: Car speed = (π × sheave diameter × motor RPM) / roping ratio. For geared machines, motor RPM is reduced by gear ratio. Larger sheaves increase speed.

questions.question: What is the purpose of rope data tagging?
options: To identify installation date and specifications for maintenance tracking
questions.explanation: Rope data tags record installation date, rope specifications, and manufacturer. This information is essential for maintenance scheduling and replacement decisions.
